1917 is a prime example of a well-produced and accurate historical film that gives the audience a real glimpse into the perspective of a solider(s) in World War I ! This entire film, in my opinion, has very purposeful elements throughout it. First off, the feel of the single-shot videography was great! The editing was top notch and I even had to question myself whether or not there were cuts in the photography or no at times, fantastic! Second, this movie had a great intentionality to it! The violence and actions were purposeful and weren't for the sake of themselves, but rather an accurate presentation of the sequences and events that occurred. You can really see the director's intention in the film clearly. The context and the presentation were executed very effectively, but be aware of its violence. The audience should be over 18 to be able to fully grasp the historical understanding of the film which is so impactful. Viewing in this lens, the film does an awesome job inspiring the audience through its main character Lance Schofield in his very heroic deeds throughout the film. His unconditional actions are absolutely rooted in fundamental truth, and his respect for people with his respectful attribution to his lost friend and soldier Lance Blake is beautiful and also inspiring. I personally was very inspired after the film and gained a much bigger appreciation for anyone who serves in the military, especially my godfather who served for many years in the marines. Overall, 1917 was a fantastic film which inspired me in a very positive way, and I know it will be doing the same for many others. I will be watching this film again very soon!

The film 1917 is a fantastic dark depiction of a near suicide mission to be completed by Lance Corporals (Lcpl) Blake and Schofield. Lcpl Blake is played by Dean-Charles Chapman, who does a fantastic job portraying a British soldier that emits innocence early on in the film. Lcpl Schofield, played by George MacKay, is a darker more experienced troop in the British war machine that has experienced more combat, and has a far less optimistic outlook on things than does his partner. The film revolves around Lcpls Blake and Schofield being given a mission to travel through no man's land, and deliver a vital message to the Devonshire line to prevent nearly 1,600 British troops from advancing into an ambush by the Germans. The Germans here had recently made a hasty retreat from their previously held line in favor of falling back to a more fortified position to bait the British forces into pursuing. One of the major reoccurring themes in the film is that of the horrors of warfare, and the toll that it takes in stripping the innocence from what are basically children.Throughout the film the camera angles used are incredibly important in giving a look into what is being experienced by the two Lcpls as they navigate through no man's land, and cross into previously held German territory. The way the camera seems to roll in a continuous shot revolving around the two Lcpls gives an incredible play by play display of the obstacles they are facing, as well as providing close ups on their faces giving insight into the human emotion involved. The camera is constantly rotating around the two as they trek through this new dangerous territory, keeping always on the alert. With this, you are able to see truly how horrific the battlefield was in WWI, with dead horses and soldiers strewn across the landscape between massive artillery craters and lines of barbed wire.Lighting in this film also plays a huge part in displaying truly how horrific war is. Back at the beginning of the film you first have Lcpls Blake and Schofield having a nap by a tree in a grassy field. It is sunny in this moment before they are awakened by their Sergeant to begin their mission. As they move out of their trench line and into no man's land, a sort of overcast covers the battlefield. It is certainly an ominous effect as they enter formerly German trenches. They are then plunged into a tunnel system in order to navigate through the lines, and the lighting is very minimal here. This effect makes you feel the terror that is experienced in a German tunnel system, especially so after they trigger a booby trap.Lighting and camera angles are utilized fantastically in this film to truly show how terrible the war is and Lcpls Blake and Schofield's personal reactions to it. Lcpl Blake is ultimately killed halfway through their mission when he is gutted with a knife by a downed German pilot. In this way, Lcpl Blake did not have the opportunity to become battle hardened by war like Lcpl Schofield, however this death certainly seems to take away whatever innocence that Lcpl Schofield had left.I personally give this movie a 10/10. Everything about the film was done in such a way that truly gives you an immersive experience. Watching the two young Lcpls as they take on this mission really hits home how horrible war is, and how it can just downright strip a young optimistic soldier of their innocence. The differences between Lcpl Blake and Lcpl Schofield at the beginning of the movie truly show the difference combat makes on one's spirit.

1917 shows a soldier Lance Corporal Blake selected for a task he assumes is medial; he chooses another soldier Lance Corporal Schofield to help. They soon learn they will be going over the top and through enemy territory to deliver a life-saving message to another unit. The two must give this message to another General before an early attack that will entrap thousands of soldiers in this other unit; Blake's brother included, they must begin their mission immediately to make it in time.
In 1917 we saw a sense of duty where these two young men have been subscribed a deadly task; ultimately, only Schofield achieves the goal. He could have quit many times through, but events along the way reinforce his sense of duty. Schofield could have stopped when the tunnel collapsed, knocked out when fighting a sniper or when the pilot killed Blake. He pushes through, each event layering hate for the enemy, building his drive to save others, or removing a way out.
Like Saving Private Ryan, our men are on a mission to save a brother; the group keeps pushing forward toward potential death. Questioning the mission turns toward a real sense of duty by the end of the film. Both movies have an anticlimactic scene when they get to the task, and the people on the other end do not want to listen to the message delivered.
1917 is a rare sort of film where the time spent watching the movie is the same length as the soldier spends on his mission. Masterful editing allows this to happen without any feeling of the camera cutting away. Viewers walk alongside the soldier from start to finish and never look away from his experience. Lightning enables the editing to keep a single thread in time by creating moments where the set can change through dark black transitions. Scene cuts additionally are obscured by explosions, dust clouds, or motion blur; never is there a noticeable cut.
The single thread in time gives viewers a sense of how life might be during the Great War and builds the viewer's sense of duty. Many other war films cut away from the horror of battle with flashback clips to better times to give viewers a break from the hopeless feeling. 1917 keeps the viewer engaged and focused on the mission, along with Schofield they want this to end, get to the resolution just as much as Schofield. Granting the audience a sense of what it might have been like to live two hours of the war.
Watch 1917 in a quiet place with a large screen and decent sound. Take it all in and join these men on their mission.

Many are also praising the cinematogrophy however I don't actually like the 'one take' style since it creates such weird inconsistencies in time.In normal moviemaking when you transition between shots, there is the opportunity to let some time pass between the shots and the viewer is aware of this. But when I watch this 'one take' style and time passes on the other side of a wall for example, I just got confused and really thought it would be better of just throwing in cuts in some places. You could still use long immersive takes without making the whole movie 'one take' for a meme or something.Regarding story and characters, this movie is just not good. The story is very simple and quite frankly, ridiculous. The characters appear very briefly and is never seen again except for the protagonists which struggle during the whole movie with walking, occationally running and lots of panting.If there would have been an interesting story with perhaps more character developments, this could have been a great movie. In reality if you have seen the trailer you pretty much have seen the movie. There is zero rewatchability.

The quietness of this movie was an instant reminder that the producers had little idea of the reality of the Western Front. From Flanders to the Swiss border you could - at any time of day or night - always hear the distant booms of artillery barrages.Also, this movie was so full of 21st-century features - non-white troops embedded with British front-line units and so on - that it's a wonder the producers didn't try to work in a lesbian subplot.As a piece of fantasy it's not half bad. "1917" is a gripping British war film, produced in 2019. The film is based on true events and narrates a few days in the life of two British soldiers during World War 1. Sam Mendes successfully created a spectacular story out of a relatively unknown incident.After realising a strategic withdrawal by German troops to start an ambush on a neighbouring battalion, Will Schofield (George MacKay) and Tom Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) were ordered to deliver this information to their threatened friends. Due to cut telephone lines the two set out on foot early in the morning. To accomplish their mission the two Britons, must escape from German front-line soldiers, cross minefields, and brave harsh weather conditions. This tense journey through northern France makes the film stand out, moreover, the acting is very convincing and well produced.The film provides a short but intriguing insight into the courageous life of two soldiers. I was particularly impressed by the plot, which was designed with meticulous detail and in a realistic manner. The structure of the film was unusual and quite new to me since the whole film only shows a period of about four days. I would highly recommend this film to anyone interested in having a look at a supposed sideshow. It is by far not a typical war film with large-scale attacks and many deaths, but it offers a very personal view from the perspective of two soldiers.

I wanted to like this movie but, after all the hyperbole and accolades heaped upon it, it failed to deliver.The plot is thin and no amount of stunning cinematography can fill in the gaps. The absurdity of sending two junior NCO's on this mission when aircraft, passenger pigeons and the good old telegraph could have easily warned the 2nd of the trap cannot be explained. The incident with the German airman left me shaking my head as the flyers of the day were notoriously civil in captivity.I wish there were more WW 1 movies to compare this with but, if you have an hour or two, watch, "All Quiet on the Western Front" with Ernest Borgnine and a young Richard Thomas and "Paths of Glory" with an amazing performance by Kirk Douglas.That is all...

This is from someone who adores stuffy documentaries. Yes, it had great cinematography, but I felt totally unengaged by it. I don't remember even the first name of the protagonist. The dialogue was too quiet and the rare bits of action were too loud.Long story short, I didn't care about the characters and I tried liking this film.I feel like people saw that it was history related and so they just thought they were SUPPOSED to like it. WWI was mostly waiting to die in a trench, but exciting things did happen. Once again, I love documentaries and I also love British movies and TV.

I went to see this film after it won 3 2020 Oscars in Best Sound Mixing, Best Cinematography and Best Visual Effects. So, in my view, I only expected to see how the director, Sam Mendes, portray WW1 scene and how he could deliver emotion of character through the camera work. The result is not disappointed and I could understand it clearly why this film won 3 of technical category awards.Before going to see this film, most people reviewed it as great in only cinematography but 'normal' or 'too cliché' in main plot. The plot is about 2 wartime messengers who got assigned to deliver vitally important at the front line on time. If you are a fan of war film, this plot might remind you of all time famous war film 'Saving Private Ryan (1998)' which is about a captain who got assigned to find a private named Ryan whose three brothers died in combat and bring him home before his family will be losing all sons. I admitted that the plot of 1917 really sounded cliché, but I have to compliment to 2 main casts including George MacKay as Lance Corporal Schofield and Dean-Charles Chapman as Lance Corporal Blake that they both could portray the feeling and pressure of wartime messengers perfectly. Their acting made me feel sympathetic to them and pray that they could accomplish their mission until the end of the movie.Plus with long-take cinematography style throughout the film and the editing such as zooming out when the main cast was in the middle of battlefield full of front line soldiers or zooming in at the main character's face when they are hiding their enemy. Again, if you are a fan of war film, you might be familiar with the film called 'Dunkirk (2017)' which use the same cinematography technique with 1917 but it had some boring editing part. In 1917 film, Sam Mendes, the director improved it flawlessly. Even though the film was not filmed long-taken in 1 shot but the editing was perfectly smooth in the level that the audiences couldn't notice that each scene was filmed separately.Moreover, the sound mixing combining with 2 components mentioned above gave this movie more powerful impact. Throughout the movie, this movie made me feel exhausting physically like I was hurrying to deliver the message along with those 2 main characters.Overall, this movie had remarkable point mostly in cinematography technique but I could say that if the movie miss another important part such as cast's acting skill or the plot, the outcome of this film would not be this successful. I will give it 9/10 because the plot is too easy to predict and will give it 10/10 if ignoring it.
One of the bset WWI films i've ever seen. Very detailed and the plot is solid. A must watch.
Not much there. Two guys wander, and then wander, and then wander, anddddd......you guessed it, they wander again. Boring, uneventful, and anti climatic.
It's means something like friendship or war or humanity I love it.

I agree with many disappointed viewers: this is a rehash (a bad one) of All Quiet on the Western Front, Gallipoli, Private Ryan, Butch Cassidy and Two Towers (the gorge, the waterfall, the jump into the rapids and all of that in flatlands Flanders of all places), and then some.All Germans are mean (and stupid because they die after getting help by the kind English soldier), the baby looked in pretty good shape after having been in a war zone for who knows how long, two messengers walk into a deep bunker / Unterstand without checking directions or whatever, but hoping it will get them "there"... Outch.The Devons are ready to go over the top in a highly contested hostile frontline, they hunker in a wide broad trench dug out of the chalky landscape (was it a battle in the Champagne?? ) and there are no craters in front of the trench anywhere, virgin land (the Germans obviously didn't know anything about scorched earth, particularly when they purposely retreat to create a trap: make the approach easy, pleasant, that'll fool the English...).I don't doubt the director's grandfather's stories. He must have been a great story teller, but even 'tall tales ' happen in context or they are just fairy tales.The film (actually the director) couldn't decide if it wanted to be a war story, a personal journey, a feel good movie, an action flick or a deep reflection on humans (i.e. Men, there was only the mom and the baby), in the end , it was neither.

Got a few issues with this film.
1. The letter. Why is is not a ball of wet mush? Even the ink isn't smudged.
2. German soldiers that went to the Star Wars Stormtroopers School I'd Learn To Shoot. Even the shrapnel couldn't hit the side of a barn.3.Trust an enemy to be quiet if you take your hand off his mouth hey?
4. Amazing that not one soldier questions- or even notices-that a unidentified wet and muddy soldier isstaggering through the undergrowth and joins them whilst listening to a guy sing...for too long.I could mention a few more (lady with baby...why does this scene even exist? The cliche waterfall. )Anyway, anybody heard of an 1981 Aussie film starring Mel Gibson, "Gallipoli "?
Well the writers of1917 obviously have.
Watch it... it's a better movie with no cgi rats in it.
I just cant even explain how well made and amazing this movie is. Just absolutely wonderful.

Periodicals are my preference so I was super pumped for this film. I didn't make it past the opening scene lol. Dean-Charles Chapman was cast as a starving teen soldier in WWI. He and his mate are walking back to camp complaining about how hungry they are, yet Chapman looks like he's had a couple slices in between each take they've shot. I don't know how anyone is supposed to take this film seriously when you can't even cut the weight to play the part. The film may have been better than I've rated it but I just can't waste 2 hours of my life watching something when the star's character isn't believable. Try again Hollywood.

I never really like war movies but this hits different. Everything about this movie is just perfect. Sam Mendes did again a great job. I need to appriciate the choice of actors. George MacKay was a great choice of a mane character becouse he has something that the other actors don't have. I don't know if it's the look or a pure talent but he definitly did a great job. Dean-Charles Chapman on the other hand was too good and I mean it in a good way becouse his acting has everything I wanted and his performemce was phenomenal. I also like the choice of supporting actors such as Colin Firth,Mark Strong,Benedict Cumberbatch, Andrew Scott... .The thing what interest me the most was the tension in every second minute. You don't know what's going to happent and you love it. Basically this movie is must watch and I definitly recommend it.

A recapitulation of World War II History of United States overall takes a modern look into what soldiers and nations fought to liberate from war and obtain liberty/ Must watch to know more details of 1917 movie.

With a unique style of a "one-shot" movie, it's script is a masterpiece, having almost not a single mistake, but being able to turn those mistakes in a way to create a bigger connection between the main character and the audience.

An incredible achievement - superb performances, beautifully shot and an outstanding testament to the brave souls who gave and risked their lives.The film captures fully the brutality of war but also the sheer innocence of those involved, reminding you that these brave young men were just that, young men caught in an unthinkable situation.The pace of the film is measured in part but also equally relentless, while the tension of the situation never leaves full respect and understanding is given to the characters, with them and their relationships portrayed beautifully.A thought provoking, relentless and ultimately very important masterpiece.

Exemplary angles and plans If you haven't watched 1917, you will lose a lot. The fact that most of the war movies secretly or openly propagandized a state and made the masses sleep with the intense nationalist sauce and made a war beautification made me very far from war movies, it also reduced my curiosity to discover a good war movie. In this regard, you have witnessed many war films, especially as I have witnessed, in which America tried to impose its ideology on the world through Hollywood. So I almost lost hope that war movies would offer something new about the tragedy of humanity. The last war movie I watched was Mel Gibson's "War Valley (2016)", but movies like "Dunkirk, Cold War, Tall Girl, Painted Bird, For Sama" that I watched later, once again removed my prejudices. Now, the movie "1917" has been added to the list of movies I have mentioned. The movie "1917" focuses on the story of two British soldiers, Blake (Dean-Charles Chapman) and Schofield (George MacKay), who crossed the enemy lines to deliver a message to their armies that would save the lives of hundreds of soldiers. Of course, it will not be easy to convey this message on foot and as soon as possible.
A really beautifully presented film. I think I enjoyed the cinematic aspect of it more than the story itself, but overall it was a really engaging film.

A small detail I'm sure not many people noticed but I found and is probably one of my favorite aspects of the story, is the story of the trees. At the start of the film we see both of our protagonists sleeping and leaning against trees when they get called for their mission. As the story goes on and one of them dies, there is a tree that has fallen over across the road blocking the soldiers path from continuing. Then at the very end of the film when our main character finishes his mission, he walks over to a lonely tree and rests upon it after a long journey. So, to me it is so cool how the trees life is telling the story of our protagonist.
A stunning beautiful (if you can call it that) film from start to finish. An impending sense of dread that not even Dunkirk managed. The sound, visuals and acting all perfect.

I quite enjoyed the entire film but one criticism (that just bothers me) Stop changing historic events by putting black actors in movies trying to change history. It's dumb and does nothing for the movie or the person watching it.

It is beautiful and a technical achievement. The story is ridiculous and I am pretty sure the Germans are Stormtroopers, because they can't hit anything numerous times in the movie. There are so many things that are utterly ridiculous that these soldiers do. Maybe WWI soldiers were that poorly trained, both German and British.
Loved the long shots, the action and felt with the guys almost instant

Sam Mendes' 1917 is an amazing cinematographic experience. You feel like you are inside the screen with those soldiers. Every word, every tear, every run depicts perfectly the fear and horror in trenches of the Great War.
This movie almost achieves perfection in every technical category and George MacKay's performance is as excellent as it is undervalued.Mendes proves that he is a "great storyteller" as his grandfather Alfred was!
10/10

This movie is an insult to the millions who suffered and died. It just does not make sense, isolated regiment (massively stagnant front line), walk into battle only (do not run due to the creeping barrage), Indiana Jones style underground explosions, float down a river in full wooden uniform, webbing and boots, finished off with a waterfall in the middle of the flattest patch of ground on earth. So blatantly hollywoodised it is a blessing that all of the veterans of that war are not alive to see it.

But no story... apart from Soldier A gets shoot, omg a trap, ohh some explaining to be done to character L whos in charge.Soldier A and B are expected to deliver a message to squadron C who's preparing an attack(while messaging pigeons existed), to avoid squadron C to be ambush in a trap... Also there's something about soldier B brother(Who I cannot bother to answer, cuz Ive gave up on seeing it, also seemed like a cheap ploy to attract on the trailers Soldier Ryan fans)

Well done semi-historical/war drama. The dialog was minimal so it was left to the costumes and sets to take us to 1917 and the Great War. And that is exactly what they did. The uniforms had an authentic look, though I'm certainly no expert in British Army uniforms, they appeared to have been well researched and were convincing. But it was the sets that took me to the 1917 trenches. I could almost feel the mud. The single shot camera work really drew the viewer right into the action. All in all, a breathtaking movie experience.
Gripping and Intense. The cinematography makes you feel you are actually in there. Amazing backscore and set. Am sure it is going to win best picture fingers crossed.

1917 is one of the greatest war movies of all time. The direction of this movie is mesmerising. A true testimony to human will and a remainder of the sacrifices that so many soldiers made during WW1.
With everything that has been going on it seems that this is the perfect time for us to reminded about the horrors of war.
One of the best war movies so far , gave it 10/10 for directing and cinematography. A must watch

This is a perfect movie. It's that simple. It's flawless. And it's not as heavy as you may think, the elements of hope and achievement lighten it up complete with some tender moments and a happy ending. With the technical execution and acting...it's perfect.
Every second of this movie keeps you on toes. A must watch!
I really don't understand all the rave reviews on this film. It is tedious and boring. The dialogue is stilted. If you enjoy watching men walk through trenches, then this is the film for you.

There was a lot of action. Some violence. An arc to a stated goal. But, it didn't make you pull for the protagonist. There was a brother that was in danger, but you never had a reason to want him to live. Very little backstory to describe him as worth saving. No special ability of the 2 protagonists to do an impossible job, other than it was one's brother. An interlude with a woman that was supposed to reflect a version or reference to home life, but didn't do it well and was never revisited save an ambiguous picture with a note (sister, wife, girlfriend...who knows?). In short, the character development was sophomoric. The story was as boring as it could be for an interesting premise. The cinematography and realism made the movie watchable. But, at no time during the movie did I think, "Wow, this is a great movie." I went to see Spies in Disguise with my son 2 days afterward and thought that that was a much better movie. Better on all fronts.
This isn't a gimmick. If you get the chance, please watch it in the cinema, it was quite an experience. I went with family members and the journey home was silent, it left the lot of us speechless.

This is my first review ever. I had to write it because I am fascinated from what I've seen right now. With all respect, Citiyane Kane, 2001: A space odyssey and 1917 are the most revolutional direction of all time. Master peace of world cinema, so glad that someone made something like this in TV era.

I've never left a review, but this one deserves all of the praises. It's one of the most beautifully done movies I have ever seen. You feel you are right there with the soldiers, getting completely immersed. The camera work, the music, the scenes, everything was on point. The two hours fly by so quickly, in the best way possible. There isn't a moment that you feel you can look away. Watching it a second time, you can truly pick up on the subtle actions of the character Schofield and why he seems shut off. You can better understand Blake and his intense desire to just go without stopping. The characters compliment each other greatly, and the actors were brilliant. Very well done!
The way this movie is shot bring you inside of the action and make you feel like you are following in the footsteps of the character.

... but a completely different experience. You are submerged during this time in the world that surrounds the main characters, close to what they're thinking/feeling. I found myself more than once trying to make the camera move to see another angle. It is impressively made.

Mendes managed to capture the suspense, the intensity, the horror, the madness & the camaraderie of this crazy, horrific episode in time called WW1. I certainly don't want to spoil anything for anyone who have not seen this movie, but it is, by far, the best war movie in quite some time.
This movie had me on the edge of my seat from start to finish. It's an astonishing piece of filmmaking

This movie is amazing! While not based on an actual event, the story is based on stories from the directors grandfathers WW1 experiences. Probably the best war movie since Saving Private Ryan (Dunkirk is up there as well). And the editors make it look like a single shot which looks incredible.

Watched the movie today. The screenplay is somehow simple: there are just two main questions whether the message will be delivered in time and action will be cancelled (vaguely said in order not to spoil anything) and whether the brother will be met. So, no other twists for me there... But an incredible cameraman work keeps interest of a viewer till the end. The gluing together of shots is so smooth that there persists an illusion that the movie is made in one shot. Also, the music - it sound with the precise scene mood at the right time which amplifies watching experience. Neverrminding the screenplay and my rating of 6 stars, it certainly worth watching at least one time.

Tried to like it, but no. Incredibly boring from start to end. At least the picture was good. But the rest, nah. The plot: a guy and his friend walking for 2 hours. They tried to put in emotional scenes but failed miserably. I usually get really moved by those, but I didn't feel anything this time. I guess it wasn't my cup of tea.

This story follows a journey, mainly shot real time...and the cinematic visuals make the viewer think they are part of the story.
Night scenes with flares give a surreal feel
and the camera operations are supremely executed. The sense of being with the 2 men is real as good as it can be.
Moving story, very well choreographed action, brilliant for the actors to play and very gritty and real looking trenches and buildingsThe story...it shows the futility of war particularly WW1.
This movie makes you feel all the emotions as if you were there. First review ever on here and this movie was worth it. From the start to finish this movie is everything you want in a war movie.

I'm really amazed at how they shot the movie ... I'm speechless.. this is definitely a 10/10

Expensive production to portray war as something of drama and emotion. War is hell and death. Kill or be killed. Those that benefit from so many giving their lives to this horror are now benefiting in the glamorization of it. Complete garbage absent of any touch with reality. Sick.

A beautiful movie, yes.
It had me, my gf and her family sitting in the couch laughing from how unrealistic a lot of the scenes were.Definitely a good thing if it were a comedy but this were supposed to be a realistic war movie.

I had high hopes for 1917......"even better than Saving Private Ryan" I heard people say. Nonsense. While it may be a technical triumph, the characters are boring, the acting from the two leads is poor, and the story is predictable. World War One involved a plethora of fascinating characters and events and was a truly paradigm-shifting moment in history......1917 is just a movie we've seen a thousand times before.....the tragic futility of war told via the experiences of a couple of generic cockney corporals with no personalities whose lives are valued at nought by pantomime villain officers that just want to send men over the top for the sheer fun of it....blah blah blah. In short, 1917 is a technically spectacular work which delivers a cliche and generic portrayal of the war.

Characters without depth, absurd situations that do not contribute anything to the plot, the direction of Sam Mendes is far from other of his acclaimed films. An horrible bad version of "saving private ryan"
Worst war film I have ever seen! Don't waste two hours of your life, most exciting bit was a van getting stuck in mud! Terrible pantomime acting!

Beautifully filmed bs story about something that never happened in a pointless war without purpose.
Badly edited storyless and with poor poor acting and ....... Why?

Wonderful in so many ways. Excellent story, great acting, sets are amazing. Quite disturbing at times, the tension rarely drops but the effect of it being filmed as a single shot is quite extraordinary. Highly recommended.

It is refreshing to watch a war movie that truly makes you feel every emotion from love, to terror, to sadness and beyond in the span of a couple of minutes.
The cinematography is a true masterpiece, seamlessly edited.
All the actors deserve a standing ovation and have my utter admiration.

This movie is intense, heartbreaking, mesmerizing, and at times stressful. The cinematography in this movie is absolutely BREATHTAKING. As someone who hates watching war movies, I'm so happy I went to see it.

As most others have said, the cinematography was amazing and the sound effects as well. But them surviving the explosion, fallen plane landing right in front of them and the multiple shots was so fake. I thought c'mon they're like Rambo!

I think this film really looks and feels like a dream. Even inception which is focused in dreams due to the immense amount of special effects fails in showing how a real dream really looks like , well at least for me. Sudden landscape changes, sudden characters appearances and almost surreal scenes make of this story a great and special movie to see.

I think the best way to describe this movie is to say that it feels like an incredible journey.The plot is absolutely one that warrants the decision to film it as if it was one shot. I know it wasn't the first film to do this, but I feel it had a more profound effect on the overall feel of this movie than this style did for others like it. It forces you to feel the weight of each passing minute, and evokes a sense of urgency like I've never experienced before.I highly recommend doing some research after watching the movie about how they designed the sets. The choice to film the movie as one shot meant they had to be extremely precise with the speed and distance the actors needed to travel during each scene to make sure the pacing of the movie made sense.I think it's fascinating how factors such as weather, lighting, and set design needed to be just right to achieve the final look they wanted. I appreciate the consideration of these minute details, as I can tell how crucial each element was in tying everything together into the masterpiece that it is. It's hard to think of a reason anyone could dislike this film - it's truly an incredible watch!
When Schofield is travelling with the caravan, there's an officer on foot who chats with him. I swear it was Stanley Tucci. But he'snoweher to be found in be credits. Did my eyes deceive me?

I watched this film on Sunday and I'll admit I started falling out of love with it as soon as the plot was established as I found it hard to believe, but then multiple things kept happening which further took me out of believing and being invested in the film and into downright incredulity most of the time. Something which I could perhaps have got behind if the movie acknowledged its dreaminess, but as it wants to be judged as a "based on real events" type basis, I'm afraid its a hard no from me on believability.So those events, which others have remarked upon: Getting blown up and surviving without a scratch, but which destabilises a supposedly well built German bunker, Star Wars mine shaft jump, who milked the cow, why is that cow still alive, why aren't they concerned that it probably means someone is around, helping the German pilot (not the last time these two are shown to be terrible soldiers), I didn't know enough about Blake to care for him before he died and I was glad when he did because the German pilot stabbing a naive Brit for pulling him out the plane was what he deserved it was just stupid, the truck fulls of Brits turning up at that moment (more on that later), Schofield not jumping in the water as soon as the sniper starts shooting, Schofield briefly becoming an incredible soldier and hitting the sniper before going back to being a terrible one, didn't roll a grenade in through the sniper door, weird back of the head injury that knocks him out, but again doesn't kill him, then disappears, more bad soldiery running down the middle of the Main Street of the town that you know has Germans in, not shooting at the soldier that comes out of the fire, just running away and being missed multiple times from extremely close range, not got a lot to say about the baby scene except he briefly loses sight of his mission, why do the Germans seem to not be looking for him in that period, again trusting a German soldier not to speak even after the lesson of the pilot, I was fully expecting him to stab the other German, but then he just runs past him... the waterfall in the river, if its the same river as the downed bridge crossing couldn't he have just crossed it at the point he eventually gets out and skipped the town? how did the 1600 soldiers get across the river? Why are they set up in the field instead of clearing and holding the nearby town? At the singing scene why are there no sentries, you are deep in what was German territory a matter of hours ago guys! we've just seen there might be snipers, Lastly, holy cow thats an impressive brand new trench, are you sure you haven't got any supply lines? Because that sort of set up looks like it would have supply lines. Getting up out the trench... meh I was gone at that point.So on to the point no one has made yet. The movie constantly undermining itself. Lets go back to the beginning, a trench full of Brits seemingly waiting to go over the top at any moment. We go through no mans land, but the German trenches are empty, so actually we worried for no reason, and the men really should have been stood down, forward to the British trucks... WHERE DID THEY COME FROM? Did someone build a road through no mans land in a couple of hours? Up to that point we are believing our two soldiers are alone behind enemy lines. But actually they aren't behind enemy lines because the trucks are there and everything is so casual! its clear they know there are no Germans around, so what was the opening of the film even for? There was ZERO danger apart from a booby trap, they should have driven there. OK Why does Schofield run into the town? As I said earlier if its the same river its really stupid, but I could go with it being a different bit of river. Back to the singing scene, everything is safe again. The way those soldiers are, its as if they are behind the line (which they sort of are) not part of some advance.OK the final bit, we are told at the start that they must halt the attack before its starts to prevent a massacre as the Germans have amassed a far superior force (this is the premise of the film, then we are told the brother went off in the first wave, but here he is, back from the first wave, alive. So how bad could this attack and the German response even have been? It would have given the film some poignancy back if Schofield wandered round the aid station, found the other dead brothers surname on a dog tag, went off to his tree and wondered about the futility of war.
The most emotional and heartfelt film I have seen for years. Don't hesitate just watch it. Awesome, I wanted to immediately see it again.
Excellent cinematography & acting. Very powerful. Would highly recommend this movie.
Anybody that claims this movie is intense should stop watching movies all together

This movie seems like it was shot with a great camera and no talent. Close up shots 75% of the movie, poor acting, horrible script writing (most doesn't even relate or make sense), way too many panning scenes done poorly. To be honest I walked out towards what I believe to be the ending of the movie. I kept hoping for better but it's a flop IMO. Not sure how this made it to main screen. Tho I believe it was the title and history content it was supposed to have. No action all. Bet they didn't spend any money on the "set". Lol needles to see I was disappointed with this movie. Save your money till it's free on Netflix.
Without doubt an instant classic the best in every aspects

It felt like watching Transformers but from the WWI set. The music felt totally out of place, thus being very repetitive in style and over scored. Couldn't make the connections.
The acting and direction were boring. Actors were generally too soft and too welcoming between each other. The environment lost its hostility based on the XXI century kindness represented in the movie. Horrifying in that sense.
The script had potential but many obvious Transformers like dialogue lines.
The makeup felt wrong at all times. All actors and extras seemed to have come directly out of a very nice shower. Actors would only look stained (as well as their clothes) after accidents, though they still managed to somehow be quite clean again.
I believe there lacked studying of this historial matter in every sense.
Visually, the lightning was very well achieved, and most of the camera shots were very nice, though sometimes the movements were a bit overdone.
CGI was noticeable in the ground explosions... even in the 70's they made it better than today. Sometimes it's just better to simulate the real thing. It's even cheaper than CGI.

Worth watching.
Not one I'll be added to my dvd collection though.
And Indians and black people were alive in 1917 so get over it.

I recently went to go and see this new film at the cinema and was very pleased with how Sam Mendez made me feel like I was actually present within the story as if I I was there in 1917 living the life of the soldiers. The way he's managed to do the film without any cuts scenes and being a continuous rolling shot of the film made you feel like you were constantly with Lance Corporal Schofield ( George Mackey ) throughout his journey of the story. Right from the beginning of the film your hooked on this emotional rollercoaster of a ride that you go though! Where it had me on the edge of my seat waiting to see what the next move was. Any giving you a look at the emotions that Lance Corporal Schofield was feeling During his journey. There were highs and low laughter and sadness and terrifying situations that you can only imagine what a soldier during that time went through, within even a short period as it is in the story but you can see how difficult and how much the soldiers went through even if it was a short timeline like the film. I was very pleased pleasantly surprised with all the surprise cameos within the film like Mark Strong, Benedict Cumberbatch, Colin firth and many more. And that you've got to see not just an inside look of the story of Schofield but the story of everyone else that is involved with his journey. This film is definitely a crowdpleaser and a must see film of 2020 and will definitely most likely be up there in one of the war films to remember along with saving private Ryan, Dunkirk and hacksaw ridge.
The story seems like saving private Ryan, but the final quality is pretty lower. good cinematography especially camerawork but the plot and characterization is awful. it's a mediocre movie
Simply amazing! A must watch for a film lover or average watcher of the medium.

Just walked out of cinema and had to post a score for this. 10/10 doesn't do it justice, amazing cinematography, still don't know how it was done. Amazing direction, Sir Sam is a genius, taking an idea he's already tried in Spectre and broadening it out, the structure, the story. What a tribute to the young men that gave their lives for our tomorrow. Faultless.
No other movie has affected me so much. I never fully considered the debt we owe to these men.
The cinematography and sets were unbelievable. Go see it just for that. But the entire film was fabulous.

I've been watching BTS videos of 1917 all week, wanting to know all about how the one shot filming process was done. Went into the film worrying that I'd hyped myself up and would be disappointed. I sure wasn't. 1917 is a masterpiece, from start to finish, gorgeous shot, beautifully acted, the music is stunning, every emotion conveyed is felt to its fullest, with such a dynamic score, from the rising tension in the bunkers, to the epic buildup during the trench run.
1917 also manages to convey the horrors of war, both physical and mental, without relying heavily on gore, it's a good balance.
I could not recommend this film any higher, do yourself a favour and watch it while it's in cinemas
A true masterpiece in filmmaking. There really is no need to go in more detail. Parasite is well deserved of all the praise, but I truly think this film should've won.
I was mesmerized by the technology used to produce this movie. This overshadowed the wonderful story and fabulous acting.

The movie sucked you in from the very beginning. The way it was shot like everything happened in one take really trips you out but also make you part of the story and keeps you on edge. I would recommend this movie to anyone.

The historical event in this epic movie of the Great War (WWI) is monumental. It begins with a simple order to get a couple of young corporals deliver a message to the colonel responsible for a large 1600 troops to attack the German opposition. The one shot camera work does an amazing job in keeping the viewer alongside the young men at all times. I Could not take my eyes off the characters. The director put me in the middle of all the action and I literally felt like it was me running around and dodging bullets. Once I started watching I was hooked. The story is a simple one and as far as any war movie I've seen I have always been intrigued by simple characters doing extraordinary things. I put this movie alongside Platoon and Saving Private Ryan for their simplistic view through the innocent eyes of young and innocent men doing their best to stay alive. War is terrible and as we see it through the eyes of the soldiers their job is to just make it alive. Sam Mendez should have won the Oscar for this masterpiece. Two thumbs up 👍🏼👍🏼

Stunned and completely lost for words. Rarely do films reach such high thrills or encompass so deep and meaningful visual storytelling. In short, 1917 is a piece to behold leaving you on the edge of your seat while never failing to grasp the profound and heartbreaking impact of the Great War.The films compelling message is also greatly enhanced by it's Soundtrack. Composed by Thomas Newman, the score is both beautiful and extremely tense. Neither is it ever overused or absent when needed most. As such 1917's Score is a perfect blend of emotional musical cues and nerve wrecking strings.It is hard to fathom what those brothers, fathers and friends have endured in those trenches or how they ever returned to society. Arguably in the scene where these men sing "The Wayfaring Stranger", a song about the plaintive soul on the journey through life - it is evident why they are often referred to as the 'lost generation'.1917 is their hymn.

Last night COL Ferry and I (COL Coldwell, both USA) were able to watch the new WWI film, 1917, before it has national release. It is a cinematographic feast for the eyes, long expansive shots that follow the protagonists as they execute their mission. It does not hide the horrors that existed in trench warfare, it shows them for their brutality and abundance. (My great uncle died as a consequence of his service fighting in the trenches, mustard gas poisoning). In many ways it reminded me of Saving Private Ryan.For those who have served in combat (I have deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan), I cannot tell you if the film will be too difficult to watch, it might well be, especially if incoming artillery is a trigger. For me, as the camera travels a few inches above the dirt advancing slowly up a berm, my response was visceral. I was taken back to the patrols we walked in Afghanistan, not knowing what was around the corner; not relaxing heightened vigilance, not knowing if there would be an IED, a child wearing a suicide vest, a sniper taking aim. For the protagonists in this film (as for all who served and are serving) surviving the climb up the berm, there is no sigh of relief, no respite from the fear of uncertainty. They (we) survive to move forward to face more uncertainty.Watching allowed me to pay homage to my great uncle, and the approximate 800,000 other Brits who were killed or died as a consequence of their service. (Germany lost over 2 million soldiers in the war). Estimates put the total casualty numbers for both military and civilians at 40 million, half killed or died from wounds/infection.I rate this film as 10/10, for many reasons. Directing, acting, set design, cinematography, musical score, the raw emotion it invokes. Some critics have said they never felt a connection with the characters, I suspect they never served in combat. While the brotherhood (including female War Fighters) is strong, there is also a common characteristic possessed by all War Fighters, the ability to focus on a mission and suppress emotion, even as those around the Fighter fall. This was the quality I recognized in the actors and why the viewer doesn't "bond" with the main protagonists; we, the viewer, were on the mission with them, we grieve as we can and move on.Watch if you will, but know there is no pleasure in watching and the film will grab you and the beginning and not let you go. Even though we know the outcome of WWI, there is no joy, there is no peace. Watch because it will allow you a glimpse at the horror and brutality of war; reflect on their service and sacrifice. Note, as we (the viewer) are "walking" through the trenches, glancing shots of the young soldiers shows them with flat affect, isolation, almost apathy; this is the face of "shell shock," what we know call post-traumatic stress disorder.For original WW1 footage, watch "They Shall Never Grow Old," an exceptional documentary.

1917 is an expertly crafted war movie that takes you right into the trenches of World War 1. The film follows two young British soldiers as they journey across No Man's Land and into enemy territory to call off an attack that will cost the lives of 1,600 men. The story is based on the account of the director's grandfather, who served in the war, and bears a stiking resemblance to the plot of Saving Private Ryan. The film delivers a deeply moving experience as you see the true human cost of war and scale of destruction left behind in what was supposed to be "The War to End all Wars". What really sets 1917 apart is the excellent Cinematography from Oscar winning DP Roger Deakins. The film is shot and edited to appear as one long take, with the exception of one intentional cut that fits the plot of the film. Although it isn't the first film to achieve this, it might be a first for a war film, which is truly impressive when considering the amount of practical effects and extras used in many scenes. This style of filmmaking really works with the story as the characters refuse to take a rest and push on with their mission, so does the camera refuse to take a break. If you are interested in history or are fascinated by the art of filmmaking, watch this movie!

Hi everyone. This is the first time reviewing a film. 1917 on the surface, from the trailers and from the reviews, seems like something you would like to see. I went into it hoping I'd learn something and feel something after two plus hours of viewing. Unfortunately this wasn't the case. The, 'one shot' choice of cinematography, at least to my mind served not only as a gimic but also as a hindrance to the entire film. I love film and I love films about war. The thin red line, full metal jacket, the hurt locker, saving private Ryan. The despair, the pointlessness of war, it resonates with me on so many levels. This film however doesn't resonate at all. I felt nothing throughout. As a brit, I've seen the first world war butchered, in wonderwoman and now used as a puff piece in 1917. I look back at that day, admittedly when I was young. There was an honesty to blackadder season 4. I was able connect to those characters. The tounge in cheek, stiff upper lip comedy, quintessentially British. Nothing in 1917 resonates like blackadder does. I remember my mother crying when baldrick and the boys went over the top and the screen disovles to a field of poppies. I remember how poininant that was for me as a child. The sacrafice those men gave. It's one of the most humbling moments in human history.It might win baftas and Oscars but 1917 is a poor reflection on the real war that unfolded 100 years ago. Its more a reflection of holywood and the self indulgent, narcassitic, style over substance agenda they are pursuing.

The only failing of this movie would, and could only be, two parts.
First: That it is so incredibly rich and full bodied in raw emotion, and delivers to us all a sense of magnitude, that one soldier can carry on his shoulders that if he dose not fulfil the duty of his orders given. This could be a over powering sense of Reality and maybe even an awakening for some, who didn't know just what the price of serving there country might be at all like in a trench or in a war. more then that, it's shows the weight of courage that only comes when the lives of your fellow man is at stake. Using the art, and magic, of the cinema it's clear to all those watching this movie, those who carried such a Humongous task in war time real were the hero's that this film proclaims then to be.
Second: the only other fault any might find is simply that this movie is so outstanding outspoken, because it has none near, or close, to its excellence in its masterful delivery as a feature film. New a fresh camera styles, that need no mention, as there awards given speak in far greater magnitude then I could tell you. Mix this with a story, that clearly holds close place in the directors/writes heart, can only equate to a masterpiece of film making artistry that Is matched in all areas around this movie. Cinematography, props, sound, lighting... any aspect that we look at closely, I can promise you won't find faults or room for improvements .
This means that such a Goliath of a movie, is stand alone at the top, only with a handful of others. Not only of its genre, but it is so rare a work of art, that is can not able but out weight its opponents, because quite simply its in a class of its own.I believe this film to be the greatest work of this masterful filmmakers that I have been privileged to enjoy, and I believe fully that as a testament to his grandfather and the service to his country, That sick a beautiful and power take upon his story would have made him overwhelmingly proud and thankful to his grandson.On a personal note, this is first first movie to ever inspire me to write a review of my feeling as the credits roll up screen, and I hope the passion of my writing over comes, what I sure I have made, is a lot of grammatical errors.Thank you, for this film.

So I felt like this was a "Saving Private Ryan" rip-off... but not nearly as good. Instead of a squad of men out to save a private, a corporal and private are ordered to save a brother and 1600 soldiers. And my first thought, only a corporal and a private are used to save a division of soldiers? Why did this get so much praise? The cinematography was incredible, the suspense and buildup were enthralling, but that's were it stopped. The story was not at all believable, the characters weren't relatable, it made the German's look like the worst shots in the war, the military tactics were deplorable, and the ending was almost humorous. Saving Private Ryan is the hallmark. Band of Brothers is a close second. Even Fury was far more interesting. Other than the visuals, this was just okay... and those English accents were hard to understand!

While the single shot may seem like a well pulled off gimmick, Mendes packs the gimmick like a master. The symbolism with the trees, character view point and soldiers are used wonderfully. The scripts maps to the gimmick but this doesn't imply it isn't good - again, Mendez wraps the script around his gimmick like a master. It is amazing the amount of perspectives Mendes gives from long view panoramas, to amazing actions scenes to views on family and military medals. Watch for story, stay for the gimmick - because it was done beautifully well.

If I had a give a quick summary, this film is breathtaking.It sounds cliche, but it is one of the few war films which made me feel like I was there, like I was in the same situation as the soldiers - helpless, with a fear that an attack could come at any time. It doesn't focus on the typical action scenes you often find in war films which present the situation as an appealing and exciting one, but shows the monotony of trench warfare and portrays the emotions these young men were feeling.One of the biggest assets to the film is the way it is shot, the single- shot camera work truly adds to this effect spoken about above. This combined with the fantastic acting and the details of the environment create, what I believe, is one of the best representations of war on the big screen. Go and see this film.

(This review has previously been posted on Chick and a Flick.)I don't like war movies, never have. They usually play one of two ways - an effects-heavy love ballad to gore and violence or a hearty tale of brotherhood among men who can't wait to talk about the girls waiting back home. The ones that focus more on fact over fiction will hold my attention a little longer, but my historical interests tend to skew towards the royal court of Henry the Eighth. So no, I don't like war movies and I didn't like 1917. I loved it.The story follows two British soldiers during the first world war and their journey across hostile territory to pass on a message that will save hundreds of lives - if they make it. Blake, played by Dean-Charles Chapman (Game of Thrones' Tommen Baratheon) and Schofield, played by George MacKay (Hamlet in the 2018 film Ophelia, which I only recently learned about and is now on my watchlist) are quickly likable and their easy, youthful friendship gives the movie a light start. Unfortunately, movies that attach you to the main characters so quickly tend to immediately send them into danger and 1917 is no exception.Schofield and Blake are called to see the general who informs them that there is an attack planned for the next morning that needs to be stopped. Turns out the Germans weren't really retreating, they were luring the British into a trap and if the attack goes on, all 1,600 men will die. Unfortunately, the phone lines have been cut and they can't call them, so the only way to warn them is by a hand-delivered letter. This is where Blake comes in - with his expert navigation skills, he should be able to make his way past the German front lines and to the camp of the 2nd battalion. In case orders aren't enough, the stakes are made even more personal when it is revealed his brother is one of the 1,600 men.They set off on their journey and we're quickly - too quickly - exposed to the horrors of war. The devastation is immediate as we are first introduced to the wounded, and then to the dead. As the pair begin their trek across no man's land, we see horrors that no man should ever have to witness and with each devastating visual, you are reminded that this isn't just a movie - this is someone's past, someone's memory.Though the story is a work of fiction, it is in fact based in some reality - director Sam Mendes' grandfather, Alfred Mendes went on his own life-threatening journey across no man's land in his time serving during World War I. These tales of war first relayed to Mendes in his childhood, stayed with him, eventually inspiring the creation of 1917.And what a creation it is. Emotionally charged from start to finish, it's hard to not judge this movie from such a personal perspective. Beyond just being visually stunning, it's the way the visuals are presented that takes it to the next level - the entire thing is made to look like one continuous take.I will admit, I was skeptical about the idea when I first heard what they were doing, but within minutes of the movie starting, I was hooked. Something happens when a movie unfolds in "real-time" and in such close proximity - you become a part of it. You're no longer watching two soldiers delivering a message during a war. You are the third soldier, a silent partner on a dangerous mission. There isn't that detached feeling of an observer, your emotions are heightened because you're experiencing it with them - the fear, the anxiety, the sadness, the determination. I will say this again and again - movies aren't just meant to be watched, they're meant to be felt and 1917 does this brilliantly.There is so much to like about the movie - the actors, the music, the story, the sheer artistry of it all - but it's the emotional core that gives it such a high place in my heart and my rating scale. This is more than just a war film - this is a story of humanity, determination, loyalty, and friendship. It's a harsh but necessary reminder of the cost of war, a hope that we can be better than we were before. It's a testament to the bond between a grandson and grandfather. It is a truly wonderful piece of art, the kind of movie that awards are made for. The stunning package is just the pretty ribbon attached to the medal.

I was a little apprehensive going to watch this film after watching the trailer and knowing who the director was (I wasn't the biggest fan of the recent James bond film spectre).I was preparing myself for an overly dramatic and glorified war movie which in parts it was, but I must admit I thought they did a good Job! I liked how the movie was shot, it really felt as if I was accompanying the protagonists of the movie step by step. It conveyed a very intermate expirience between the protagonists and the viewer coupled with some thrilling and nailbiting cinematics causing me to pull off some grimising facial expressions throughout. A quick search of top rated titles have only two movies rating over 9. Why are there are SO MANY user ratings at 9.5 or 10 for 1917? Is this movie really almost perfect? Far from it. I enjoyed the technical aspects of the film making immensely, however it was the one shot idea that made the movie ultimately unsatisfying. Great idea, but overplayed to the detriment of the pacing and story. I got bored several times due to having to follow the actors constantly. Followed by brain mashing cliche after forced plot after totally improbable scenario that seemed crammed in to allow the one shot feel of the story to flow.Nothing wrong with the idea, but not the entire movie. There are many parts to the story that worked well using this style, however Children Of Men did it better because they chose where to have the one take scenes for maximum impact.After 1917 I felt a bit like I had drunk too many beers, I felt good for a while, but the goodness didn't last for the whole experience. I should have known when to stop, Sam Mendes didn't.

My Great Uncle, Rifleman William Phillips R5080, was a member of the same Battalion as Sam Mendes's grandfather, to whom the film is dedicated, the 1st Battalion, the King's Royal Rifle Corps. Unlike Sam's grandfather, William was killed in action and did not survive to tell his stories or have a family. This was 17 February 1917, about 2 months before the film is set, and he was buried in a shell hole where, so far as we know, he remains today. He was one of the 73000 who remain unidentified. However, to commemorate the centenary of William's death, I travelled to the Somme, to Miraumont where William was killed. Before doing so I extensively researched the King's Royal Rifle Corps. I read the Battalion War diary and countless books on the action in which my great uncle was killed. While I do not wish to challenge any of the stories on which this film is based, I do have a couple of observations. The action in which William was killed was described as the worst going for infantry in the whole Somme campaign. This may not have applied in April, but the few photographs that exist show a terrain far worse than the film describes. The mud was knee deep and completely littered with line after line of barbed wire and layered trenches. By comparison 1917, while muddy up to a point, gives the impression of a country walk. I do not understand why what is obviously a dry dock was used to play the part of a river, nor can I find white water rapids anywhere in Northern France, still less a large waterfall. I'm afraid that for me this detracts from the authenticity of the film. As a piece of theatre it is a good film, but as a tribute to the actual conditions that soldiers faced, it is an understatement.

I had high hopes for this film. I love war films of this genre. From a visual and cinematography perspective, this film is really impressive. The colours and expansive landscapes are spellbinding and the trench scenes are particularly gripping and immersive. Clearly a lot of work went into this film to make it as realistic as possible and make you feel like you really were there watching live.However, I think the big challenge for this film is that the third person view / one shot principle was followed to the extreme and honestly I felt I was watching a third person shooter console game.For example, there is a scene where Schofield and Blake reach the outskirts of a farm with an orchard and outbuildings. The combination of the atmospheric music and camera angle as they walk through the broken wall and survey the farm buildings in the hollow of the valley below looks like a cut scene from Call of Duty.Maybe this was the intended effect by the Director but for me, it seemed hyper-real - almost unbelievable. After 2 hours of this, the novelty had well and truly worn off and I was pretty bored with the whole thing. There were really disctinct 'levels' to the film / game and travelling sections inbetween the levels which made it all the more feel like a game being completed.Finally the characterisation of the soldiers was in my opinion quite thin, not much in the way of a backstory or insight into their personal lives other than then odd conversation about life back home with little in the way of detail. Again, this might have been deliberate but I wasn't really rooting for the main characters to succeed.Oh and two or three pretty pointless cameos to try and jazz the whole thing up couldn't really save a dreary and uninspiring plot and a rather unsatisfying experience.So overall, nice visuals and will while away a couple of hours but nothing for me to make this film very memorable.

A new movie about World War I, haven't you had enough of these movies yet?
The two great wars (as they are called in most historical literature) were the most prominent events of the twentieth century ever, and perhaps the most prominent events in the history of mankind. It is said that one of the most important characteristics of human blood is that it is difficult to get rid of it completely. These two wars have claimed the lives of more than 100 million people. It is no wonder that they are engraved in human memory, with all this blood that does not disappear.
For all this cinema does not stop quoting stories from these two wars, but in reality if we look at the matter more broadly, we will find that all the arts are nothing but recycling of the human story, including with it even to the first sin that was the reason for the existence of man on these Earth. All human stories throughout human history, from the pharaohs' papyri, their excavations, and their inscriptions on the temples dating back thousands of years, through Greek mythology and its various myths, and ending with cinema that did not witness its birth until a century and a half ago, all revolve around the human being and recycle his first story that does not Stop repeating, so why are we asking the cinema to stop returning to the two wars?
In British director Sam Mendes' movie (1917), and as the promotional trailer tells us, we are following the story of two soldiers assigned to an urgent mission to save 1,600 soldiers from the trap set by the Germans. For two hours, when the story of the film does not depart from this narrow framework, we continue this journey in an almost realistic experience. So what might the new movie Mendes bring? In other words, how did Mendes recycle the story of World War I?
Escape to the truth
The movie is truth 24 times a second, and every cut is a lie.
French director Jean-Luc Godard
If we are going to talk about repeating the stories, there is nothing wrong with repeating the famous story of the movie "The Train Arrived at LaSoute Station" by the Lumiere brothers, which was shown in 1896. The fans, who were watching this technical miracle for the first time in history, thought that a train was moving towards them and on And about to break into the big screen, the audience panicked and won their seats.
This story is always cited in the talk about cinema between fiction and reality. With the development of viewing experience, and the development of cinematographic techniques by extension, the viewer became more aware, but he did not answer an answer to the question of truth and fiction.
In the 1917 movie, director Sam Mendes chose to narrate the film - which takes place over one day - continuously as if it were one shot and if it was not already, as the scenes were designed so that all the montage pieces are not noticeable, which is the method that preceded It was previously presented in a number of experiments, most notably the movie "The Robe" by the great director Alfred Hitchcock, and "Birdman" by the Mexican director Alejandro Enrieto.
Here in 1917, Mendes aspired to present time in his closest realism, in order to intensify the public's experience of the story, heroes are racing against time in order to complete their mission and save a large number of soldiers from meeting their deaths free of charge, and through this method the tension that this massive task creates It is the viewer's responsibility that belongs to the second decade of the twenty-first century, and a whole century separates it from these events.
As time progresses, the films acquire the adjective "classic", and a new classification called "the new classic" appears, which are works that, even if they are closer to their predecessors, but they are old enough to launch the adjective of the classic, and from this standpoint, films such as: (The Great Escape) may be 1963), Patton 1970 classic films, and other films such as Saving Private Ryan 1998 and The Thin Red Line 1998, as each generation has its own classics. Extending the streak straight, modern films like 1917 are potential classics for the newest generation of viewers.
This newer generation does not see just another story of world war, but watch it in the vocabulary of its time, and its mechanisms and modern techniques, and re-live a story that he does not belong historically, but he can identify with it humanly, which brings us back to the question of truth and imagination, and to the saying of the great French director Jean Luke Godard, in which montage pieces are like lying.
When the viewer in a dark hall follows a number of actors re-simulating a fictional or realistic story, he realizes that what he is seeing is not the truth, and that this actor who was killed on the screen did not really die in reality, but at the same time he experiences completely real feelings.
This meticulous selection of montage style deepened the reality of the viewing experience, and made it easy for the viewer to identify with the story's heroes, their sense of time and its centrality, whether at the level of the drama or the level of narration that increases the dose of excitement and suspense awaiting the unexpected that can be expected. But at the same time, he brought the movie closer to Hitchhiker's style, with more focus on action than drama.
Although the camera that follows the heroes throughout the movie does not skimp on the viewer with many pictures that convey the true face of this war, the suffering of the soldiers who are fighting death at every moment, and sheds little light on the position of the military leaders in their dealings with thousands of lives, but all of that It comes on the sidelines of the main line, which focuses mainly on the excitement-wrapped mission that attracts viewers to the edge of their seats for two hours, and they only occupy one question: Will the two soldiers succeed in saving an entire battalion from death?

So grave is the subject matter, and so infuriating the execution, I am forced to lament the exceedingly poor choices made by the director and the scriptwriter of this otherwise epic production.
Unbearably cringe-worthy and trite dialogue is the mainstay of this film.
Given the gravity of the historical subject and the truly visceral and real experience that should accompany any review thereof, I am very saddened by the pathetic treatment of the narrative evinced by the blithe, uninspiring and predictable dialogue. For goodness sake! If you're going to go to the expense and hard work of such a production, at least employ an exemplary writer and director!

Clearly, putting actors through war just so they'll be able to portray soldiers in battle believably is nothing a sane person would consider. But that doesn't mean that doing what 1917 does is a good idea: having soy boys portray men of arms. The performance of the main actors makes it just too painfully obvious that, growing up, they were never yelled at, slapped, punched and never had to endure any other significant amount of physical discomfort, i.e. never went hungry, never froze and, presumably, never had to walk more than a few bus stops. Being unable to fathom/understand even low-level intensity of violence and suffering, they seem bizarrely out of place in a WWI-setting. And that, in turn, makes for something worse than just a boring and non-immersive movie: a mockery of the unimaginable pain and sacrifice their grandfathers went through in order to keep Europe free.
A masterpiece with simple straight forward writing but an immersive story!

1917 is ultimately a frustrating experience, more than anything, given the expectations and hype around the film, and talk of Oscars. Hype in which the film does not live up to. 1917, is a film that is, in my opinion, perfect for those who are easily impressed, allow me to explain.I will start with the positives, 1917 is a beautifully and audaciously shot film. It is split into two long, unbroken shots, a commendable feat. This is to give the audience a perspective of the horrors and chaos that comes with war and to give the audience a sense of exhaustion throughout the film, the latter, I believe is achieved. The former? I'll get to that.The cinematography is at times stunning. It has one of my favourite shots of any movie around the midway mark of the film and an action sequence in the finale that will win many viewers over. The soundtrack is also a positive and helps to build tension, as well as it possibly can.The problem with all of this is, while the movie looks beautiful, it has very little substance to back it all up. Yes, the film is shot in two parts and that is meant to portray what war is really like, but that all counts for nothing when the movie is in essence, a poor portrayal of war. This is, by all accounts, a sterilised, Hollywood version of war, where the only emotion that truly shines through is courage.The acting, while solid, does nothing to help. Neither Dean-Charles Chapman nor George MacKay deserve awards for their respective performances because neither delivered on what they set out to achieve in their portrayal of the main characters. MacKay was the stand out of the two but fell short in many of his pay off moments. Whether the blame rests solely with them or is shared with the director is a discussion that could be had.The most troubling aspect of this film is, without a doubt, it's attempt to explore it's themes. As already discussed, the attempt to portray the horrors of war, missed its mark, but many other themes, such as the futility of bravery, hopelessness and what comes after war, were fumbled through almost comically and the opportunity to give any message as a takeaway, was missed each and every time.For these reason I say that 1917 is a film perfect For those easily impressed, It looks stunning and has all the bells and whistles, but lacks any substance. I likened the experience to a roller coaster, lots of fun and definitely fast paced but ultimately there is nothing to take from it because if you've been on one roller coaster, you've been on them all. 68/100

Before watching this movie I've heard plenty of people complaining that it was boring or that nothing actually happens. Nothing falser, the film is not only a good story of war, but also a lore of survival and a cinematography wonder. The idea of shooting the film in a continuous frame made the watchers feel more like they were right besides the soldiers on their journey through fire and death. Truth be told, there were couple of moments where the film seemed a little dragged, but in the end, for those who have a clue about WWI, that's how the entire war actually felt like: static and dragged. The way they managed to recreate the atmosphere of those times could have competed with a documentary in certain ways.
Therefore, 1917 is, in my opinion a story of survival, somehow similar to what Nolan attempted with Dunkirk, only better, grace to the brilliant idea of taking the watcher from his seat, right in the middle of WWI, through the continuous shot technique.

Loved the photography, and the equipment and uniforms were mostly correct in their detail.However, the plot is explained by Colin Firth, that the British reconnaisance aeroplanes have produced 'aerials', showing an unprecedented build-up of German forces, and that if the Devons proceed in their attack, they will walk into a trap, therefore, the two designated soldiers must deliver the message before it's too late.I couldn't help think, if they have the evidence in the form of aerial photographs, and they plainly already know the location of their own attacking forced, why on earth can't they drop messages to the Devons, via the same Royal Flying Corps aeroplanes, directly to the Devons? That thought was immediately reinforced in the scene where British aircraft shot down the German in front of our two central messengers.I saw my point is listed as a frequently asked question.
